title: Alfred Stelzner
text:
Alfred Stelzner (29 November 1852 – 9 July 1906) was a German <a href="composer">composer</a> and <a href="luthier">luthier</a>.
Stelzner was born in Hamburg, Germany, and educated in music, physics and mathematics. He produced <a href="string%20instrument">string instrument</a>s of his own design in Wiesbaden and then in Dresden. Two instruments of his invention were the <a href="violotta">violotta</a> and the <a href="cellone">cellone</a>. The violotta is tuned an <a href="octave">octave</a> below the <a href="violin">violin</a>, and possesses a <a href="timbre">timbre</a> between that of the <a href="viola">viola</a> and <a href="cello">cello</a>. The cellone, a large <a href="cello">cello</a>, is tuned between the cello and <a href="string%20bass">string bass</a>. His instruments received praise and endorsements from major figures of the day, including <a href="impresario">impresario</a> <a href="Alfred%20Schulz-Curtius">Alfred Schulz-Curtius</a>, and the German composer <a href="Felix%20Draeseke">Felix Draeseke</a> composed his string quintet in A major, named the "", specifically for Stelzner instruments.
Stelzner began production of his new instruments in 1889 and continued to make them until 1900. He vigorously promoted his instruments through advertising and obtained endorsements from many famous musicians of the day, including <a href="Joseph%20Joachim">Joseph Joachim</a>, <a href="Eug%C3%A8ne%20Ysa%C3%BFe">Eugène Ysaÿe</a>, <a href="David%20Popper">David Popper</a>, and <a href="August%20Wilhelmj">August Wilhelmj</a>. In addition, he helped sponsor competitions in various categories such as <a href="Symphony">symphonies</a>, <a href="opera">opera</a> and <a href="chamber%20music">chamber music</a>. His own works included the operas ' (1902) and ' (1903), as well as the never performed ' and '.
Stelzner's company eventually failed and entered bankruptcy. Faced with overwhelming financial difficulties, Stelzner committed <a href="suicide">suicide</a> at his home in Dresden in 1906.
